p: The real financial cost has two components: direct (health-related) and indirect (production losses, informal care and losses in wellbeing). It has been estimated that the total cost of health care for visual impairment in 2010 reached $1100 billion globally, excluding uncorrected refractive errors; the global financial cost reached $2954 billion. These costs include inpatients care, treatment, general eye services, and community and elderly people care, among others. In addition, associated costs of traumatism due to the visual impairment have been included [ 134].
